Award.AwardTitle: North Carolina LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate Program at NCA&T (2015-2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on Ph.D. matriculation and completion. For the U.S. to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy. North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NCA&T), a Historically Black University and lead institution for the North Carolina LSAMP (NCLSAMP), will serve as the host institution for the 2015-2017 cohort of BD Fellows. The NCLSAMP BD Program is designed to assist students' academic and social integration into the graduate school culture through a structured advisement and mentoring model. The strategies employed will contribute to the goal of increasing the quantity of well-trained, highly-skilled STEM professionals from underrepresented groups. Ultimately, these efforts would enhance diversity and representation in academia and the STEM workforce, thereby increasing the nation's competitiveness.

The overall objectives of the BD Program at NCA&T are to recruit nationally a cohort of 12 former LSAMP students into STEM graduate programs at NCA&T and demystify the graduate degree process through intensive academic enrichment, professional development, involvement in faculty-led research, and mentoring. The activities, which are designed to assist the successful transition and retention of the BD Fellows, include: (i) regularly scheduled meetings with BD staff; (ii) financial support to attend and participate in professional meetings and seminars; (iii) active engagement in research during the academic year and summer; (iv) presentations at national conferences; (v) visitations to graduate research laboratories at other research-intensive institutions; and (vi) intensive preparation for application to selected STEM doctoral degree programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Fellowship Program at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T) was developed to facilitate the recruitment and retention of STEM graduate students into the university and to assist in their successful transition into Master's and PhD programs.  Project goals, as articulated in the funded proposal, were to: recruit a cadre of STEM graduate students who have potential for academic success and a desire to pursue a STEM PhD; retain BD Fellows by providing professional development workshops, financial support and experiences to promote successful matriculation; and assist students in making the transition to graduate studies and ultimately to PhD programs. Specifically, the Bridge to the Doctorate sought to retain 100% of program participants in North Carolina A&T Master's level STEM majors and provide professional development and student support activities to facilitate student transition to North Carolina Agricultural &Technical State University graduate studies and PhD programs.

THE BD program at North Carolina A&T State University successfully enrolled 12 STEM Master’s students.  The cohort was comprised of four males and eight females. Eleven fellows identified as African American and one (male) identified as Native American. Fellows were enrolled in two-year thesis-based Master’s programs in Biology (4), Applied Mathematics (3), Integrated Animal Science (3), Bioengineering (1) and Industrial and Systems Engineering (1).  Students participated in a BD Orientation program which welcomed them to NCA&T and provided an overview of both the BD program and graduate studies at NCA&T.  Workshops to ease the transition to graduate study and assist in the application to PhD programs were offered throughout the program and included the following topics: “Managing the Graduate School Experience”, “GRE Prep”, “Graduate Research Fellowship Application Training”, “Successful Grant Writing”, “Thesis and Dissertation Writing Workshop”, “Work Life Balance and Stress Management”. Students also participated in workshops and trainings offered by NC-LSAMP, their respective departments, and the Graduate College. BD fellows attended national and regional conferences, where they participated in professional development sessions and presented research findings. Among the conferences attended were the Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference, Minorities in Agriculture, Natural Recourses and Related Sciences (MANRRS), GEM GRAD Lab, and the NC-LSAMP Annual Research Conference. One BD fellow participated in a Summer Research experience in Belize.

To date, nine (75%) BD Fellows have earned Master’s degrees, four (three African American females and one Native American male), have been accepted into PhD programs, one is currently pursuing PhD in Mathematics at Texas Tech University. The others will begin PhD programs in the fall at North Carolina A&T State University (Mechanical Engineering), North Carolina State University (STEM Education) and Meharry Medical College (Immunology).  Program assessments identified that being a part of a cohort which was going through the same experiences and the financial support as being key components of the BD program that contributed to their success.

The Bridge to the Doctorate at North Carolina A&T State University contributes to achieving societal goals, as articulated by the National Science Foundation, through intellectual merit and broader impact. Specifically, BD fellows have engaged in cutting edge research in the fields of biology, animal science, mathematics and engineering and have shared research finding at regional and national professional conferences. As PhD students, they will continue to contribute to the generation of new knowledge in Mathematics, STEM Educations, Immunology and Mechanical Engineering; areas that are critical to the national interest.  Additionally, as members of groups historically underrepresented in STEM PhD programs, NC-LSAMP BD fellows will be actively engaged in expanding the frontiers of science and engineering as they bring to the academic and research enterprise the potential for paradigmatic shifts based upon differing world views, priorities and epistemologies. They will also continue to serve as role models and mentors for younger students, as they did in their tenure as BD fellows.  Their presence in STEM PhD programs communicates to other URM students; undergraduate and younger, that STEM careers in the sciences and engineering are obtainable and worth pursuing.
